abstract.text: This review summarizes the current experimental results on rare B 0 (s) → µ + µ − decays of the Tevatron experiments CDF and D0, and the LHC experiments ATLAS, CMS and LHCb.

The experimental branching fraction upper limits for the B 0 s → µ + µ − are already quite close to the branching fraction predicted by the Standard Model, and the first observation of the B 0 s → µ + µ − decay is expected soon.

The rare decays B 0 (s) → µ + µ − are highly suppressed in the Standard Model, and therefore accurate measurements of these branching fractions provide complementary constraints to the free parameters of various extensions of the Standard Model.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
The decay channels B 0 (s) → µ + µ − are flavour-changing neutral current processes, which are forbidden in the Standard Model (SM) at the tree level, and occur only via higher order diagrams.

body_text.text: PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK
The CMS and LHCb experiments have good chances for the first observation of B 0 s → µ + µ − in 2012, if the branching fraction is in the range predicted by the SM.
body_text.section: PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: In 2012 it is expected that ATLAS and CMS experiments will collect an integrated luminosity of at least 20 fb −1 each, on top of the 5 fb −1 collected in 2011.
body_text.section: PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: LHCb will collect an integrated luminosity of 1.5 -2 fb −1 , to be added to the 1 fb −1 collected in 2011.
body_text.section: PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: It is unlikely that the decay B 0 → µ + µ − would be observed at the LHC any time soon, without very significant enhancements to the SM rate.
body_text.section: PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Nevertheless, searches for B 0 → µ + µ − will be pursued as a long-term goal.
